column4: If I can find /lib/modules/2.6.17-10-generic/kernel/drivers/net/wireless/rt2x00/rt61pci.ko, with modprobe, and rt61 is my wireless card chipset, does that mean I have a driver for it, and wouldn't need ndiswrapper?
then it is working

But that's not my point, I'm trying to 1 Make sure it will work without ndiswrapper after I reinstall, and also help someone get another wireless card working, and I found his chipset .ko on my computer, but it's not on his
if you have a kernel module, you probably don't need to use ndiswrapper
the .ko files come with the kernel that you have installed, if your friend has the same kernel he/she should have the same kernel modules
Thank you we found it on his, not sure why modprobe didn't find it for him, but his wireless card is listed under eth1, is that right?
And is also unassociated
that seems good. if it doesn't auto-associate you can set the wireless settings with iwconfig, and do dhcp with dhclient
How do you make it associate?
something like this: iwconfig eth1 essid name_of_wireless_network key wep_hex_key_here
Okay, but why is it unassociated, shouldn't it say the wireless card name in that spot?
And why is wireless on eth, I thought eth was wired
somehow udev/iwconfig and the module collude to pick an interface name, i'm not sure how
in the unassociated spot it should say the wireles network you have associated with
I thought that's what ESSID was
yeah it is, i guess i was confused about where it was displaying not associated
Ok, yeah unassociated it after eth1 but before essid
How can i make it recognize that driver file we found earlier?
it is already loaded, if it wasn't the interface wouldn't be in iwconfig at all
i think you need to do dhclient now
Okay, it's otateossian that I am helping with this, but I have a similiar issue with a different card
Mine says my card name though, and it's under ra0 not eth1
Would depmod be of any help?
maybe, i'm not sure
